dt: {bc}a case for a blade (as of a knife)
{bc}an investing cover or case of a plant or animal body or body part: such as
{bc}the tubular fold of skin into which the penis of many mammals is retracted
{bc}the lower part of a leaf when surrounding the stem
{bc}any of various covering or supporting structures that resemble in appearance or function the sheath of a blade: such as
{bc}a woman's close-fitting dress that is usually worn without a belt

et: Middle English {it}shethe,{/it} going back to Old English {it}scǣþ, scēaþ{/it} (Northumbrian {it}sceǣþ{/it}), {it}scēþ,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*skaiþjō{/it} or {it}*skaiþō{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}skēthe{/it} "sheath," Old Saxon {it}skēdia, skēthia,{/it} Old High German {it}skeida,{/it} Old Icelandic {it}skeiðir,{/it} plural), probably noun derivative of {it}*skaiđan-/skaiþan-{/it} "to separate, divide" {ma}{mat|shed:1|}{/ma}

The original meaning of the Germanic noun was presumably "something split, separated," i.e., two pieces that are split (literally or metaphorically) and that together held the blade; note that the Old Norse noun was plural (the singular {it}skeið{/it} meant "weaver's reed, silver spoon").
shortdef: a case for a blade (as of a knife)
an investing cover or case of a plant or animal body or body part: such as
the tubular fold of skin into which the penis of many mammals is retracted

dt: {bc}to put into or furnish with a {a_link|sheath}
{bc}to plunge or bury (a weapon, such as a sword) in flesh
{bc}to case or cover with something (such as sheets of metal) that protects

et: {it}Middle English Dictionary{/it} cites Old English {it}unscēaþian,{/it} but the source for this word is not established.
shortdef: to put into or furnish with a sheath
to plunge or bury (a weapon, such as a sword) in flesh
to withdraw (a claw) into a sheath

dt: {bc}a knife having a fixed blade and designed to be carried in a sheath

shortdef: a knife having a fixed blade and designed to be carried in a sheath

dt: {bc}the insulating covering that surrounds an {d_link|axon|axon} with multiple spiral layers of {d_link|myelin|myelin}, that is discontinuous at the {d_link|nodes of Ranvier|node of Ranvier}, and that increases the speed at which a nerve impulse can travel along an axon

shortdef: the insulating covering that surrounds an axon with multiple spiral layers of myelin, that is discontinuous at the nodes of Ranvier, and that increases the speed at which a nerve impulse can travel along an axon —called also medullary sheath
